conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D change with light source movement.
Objects are a clock, egg, die, and typewriter with shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
Shadow A is of the clock, a round blue object.
Shadow B is of the egg, a small oval object.
Shadow C is of the die, a small cubic object with dots.
Shadow D is of the typewriter, a rectangular object.
Current light source is above and slightly to the right of the objects.
Shadow A is cast downward and slightly to the left.
Shadow B is cast downward and slightly to the left.
Shadow C is cast upward and slightly to the left.
Shadow D is cast to the right and slightly downward.
Light source is not directly overhead but angled from top-right.
Back means moving light source further from viewer, left or right means horizontal shift.
Shadows move opposite to light source direction.
Moving light source back reduces shadow size and increases sharpness.
Shadow shape depends on object shape and light angle.
Moving light to back left shifts shadows to front right.
Shadow A will shift downward and to the right.
Shadow B will shift downward and to the right.
Shadow C will shift downward and to the right, likely below the die.
Shadow D will shift downward and to the right, moving further from the typewriter.
Shadows become smaller and sharper with light moving back.
Clock's shadow may elongate slightly.
Egg's shadow may stretch or compress.
Die's shadow may distort slightly.
Typewriter's shadow may elongate or shift.
